You've recently commented on how policymakers may find it easier to identify with the bankers than with their victims, and are thus inclined to want to go easy on their "own kind".

But it's clear that banks won't be inclined to clean up their acts if they'll be treated with kid gloves if they get caught defrauding their customers. It's simply a cost-benefit calculation.

If those responsible were to actually go to jail as a result of their fraudulent activities, they might be less inclined to take the risk. After all, the bank's money isn't their money, but they're the ones who would serve the time if they would actually be sent to prison for fraud.

And the economy would benefit from having less bankers willing to risk having a house of fraudulent cards collapse, taking the financial system with it.

@paul #136

Don't know what Longman was doing during the first half -- watching a rerun of the the Sounders-Colorado match? Of course things changed after Cheney couldn't return. The frustration we are feeling is somewhat like what the French endured -- playing beautifully for a disappointing result. Of course, that's soccer sometimes. But this was the USWNT's best effort in terms of holding the ball and keeping the initiative early in the game.

@TDK #141 & Jesse S. #148 -- Fervently agree...with 20-20 HINDSIGHT. But without benefit of that I think you must give Sundhage more credit for the promotion of Rapinoe and Morgan than demerits for Heath...which indeed did prove a blunder. As to why Pia made that decision, my speculation is that it was due to Rapinoe's involvement/ interference with a clearance in front of goal late. The US got lucky but you could see the defender looking askance up at her, as if to say "What on earth are you doing to me!" It's also possible Sundhage just thought her legs were blown. But Heath certainly didn't hold the ball well and failed to put a shot on frame in the wake of the red card restart. It was a bad idea to let her take one of the 5 kicks at the end with Morgan and O'Reilly available. It was even a worse idea to let Boxx lead off again after what happened against Brazil. THAT may have been the straw that broke the camel's back in retrospect.

But this minutia shouldn't obscure a brilliant effort that just came up short against an equally brilliant and marginally more inspired team. The future with players like Rapinoe and Morgan on the way is bright. But more than anything I think we should be celebrating not just the play of Abby Wambach -- but the woman herself. She never stood taller than fielding those galling questions -- "How much does it hurt? Whose do you blame? How come you weren't perfect?" As long as we're producing female athletes of such quality I think US sports is doing well. She's a real champion!

Bummer of a loss for the US women, for sure, but beyond the USA athletes, I couldn't have wished success on a more deserving team than Japan. Congratulations to competitors on each team for their their speed, tenacity, formidable skill and spirit. Japan had the tools to win at the end; the USA did not -- not this year, anyway. Now the US side has a real benchmark to target for 2015. In the meantime second-best in the world is no mean accomplishment. America is proud of their young women and of their World Cup-winning Japanese opponents, too.

When I left health care administration in 2001, all these problems existed and were talked about, just the same as today.  It is now 2011, ten years later, and things are even worse.  I am truly puzzled by our society's inability to confront the issues surrounding health care.   Ignoring a truly dysfunctional system won't make it better.  Tinkering around the edges won't make it better.  Many of us with "good" insurance are only one medical catastrophe away from bankruptcy (#1 cause of bankruptcy).   Are we happier with the devil we know and therefore just plain afraid of change?

Time for a quiz (med school style). You are a resident in general surgery.

An adult with a history of Peptic Ulcers secondary to Helicobacter pylori presents to the ER at 6 AM with severe abdominal pain radiating to the back. Movement worsens the pain. Temp is 100 degrees F, BP is 105/60 mmHg, pulse is 120 bpm, and respiration is 22 breaths per min.The patient lies flat and motionless.Upon examination, the patient exhibits marked tenderness when the ER doctor palpates the abdomen superficially, and the patient protests deeper palpation. The ER doctor orders labs, Xrays, and surgical consult.The nurse draws the labs and establishes I.V. access. Before the lab results return, you arrive through the back entrance and happen to see a standing Chest Xray showing pneumoperitoneum that a med student indicates as “free air.” When you examine the patient, your findings are the same as the ER doctor.

Which is the correct answer in the real world:

A)Recommend fluids intravenously and wait for the labs
B)Recommend blood cultures and antibiotics intravenously
C)Recommend a stool sample with heme occult test
D)Recommend an EKG with serial serum cardiac enzymes
E)Recommend a CT Scan of the chest and abdomen
F)Recommend an Upper Endoscopy
G)Recommend intubation and admission to the Intensive Care Unit
H)Arrange for immediate surgery (Exploratory Laparotomy)
I)Sign off the consult until appropriate for the surgical team
J)Review the patient’s insurance
K)Answers A, C, & J

The correct answer is H. A peptic ulcer probably perforated the stomach. This is a surgical emergency requiring surgical exploration of the abdomen to prevent death within 12-24 hours. In the real world, no surgeon would wait for the labs, order further tests, review the patient’s insurance, or allow elective surgery (breast cancer mastectomy, colon resection for ulcerative colitis, etc.) to take priority. The patient may be comatose without any id or available insurance info, but we would operate ASAP!

This is obviously the result of the RepublicanCare health care system.
Everyone will just have to get used to it.

"Since 1986, when Congress passed a bill that made emergency care a legal right", is a false statement and making the statement implies a responsibility that doesn't exist. The Emergency Medical Treatment and Active Labor Act. A right is universal, exists without action by the government and the most a government can do is protect the right and allow it to be exercised. A government cannot create a right, as they are natural, but it can create an entitlement. EMTLA is neither. It is, as was the "national speed limit" of 55 mph, an exercise of the power of the purse. A hospital has to provide care only if it is a participating member, i.e. is reimbursed by the government for any services. A private hospital refusing Federal payments (yeah, right) is free to disregard EMTLA.
Some might call the distinction moot, but it is very real. Allowing people to think they have a right to something they do not creates false expectations which leads to frustration and then anger. If, as the writer states, there exists a right to emergency treatment, then why are hospitals allowed to close emergency rooms which lose money? That is tantamount to states disestablishing polling places because they are just too expensive, or eliminating the public defender's office because it, too, costs money.
It would be nice if you'd include a photo of a black widow...
